hints_html:
As it says in the question statement, given \(n\), an even integer, and an upper bound \(K \geq |f^{(4)}(x)|\) for all \(x\) in the interval \([a,b]\), the error that comes from using Simpson’s Rule is as follows:

\[\begin{aligned} |I - S_n| \leq \frac{K (b-a)^5}{180\cdot n^4}\end{aligned}\]

How would you find K?
hints_raw:
As it says in the question statement, given <math>n</math>, an even integer, and an upper bound <math> K \geq |f^{(4)}(x)|</math> for all <math>x</math> in the interval <math>[a,b]</math>, the error that comes from using Simpson's Rule is as follows: 

:<math> |I - S_n| \leq \frac{K (b-a)^5}{180\cdot n^4}</math>

How would you find ''K''?
question: 7 (c)
sols_html:
We will use the hint in the statement of the problem: if we can find an upper bound K on \(|f^{(4)}|\), then we know that \(|I - S_4| \leq \frac{K (b-a)^5}{180\cdot 4^4}\).

First we find an upper bound on \(f^{(4)}\).

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= -x^{-2} \\ f''(x) &= 2x^{-3} \\ f^{(3)} &= -6x^{-4} \\ f^{(4)} &= 24x^{-5} \end{aligned}\]

On our interval of integration, [1,2], \(|f^{(4)}(x)| \leq \frac{24}{1^5} = 24\). So our upper bound on \(|f^{(4)}|\) is K = 24.

Now we simply plug this into the error formula given above to get:

\(|I - S_4| \leq \frac{24 (2-1)^5}{180\cdot 4^4} = \frac{24}{180\cdot 4^4} = \frac1{1920}\).
sols_latex:
We will use the hint in the statement of the problem: if we can find an
upper bound \emph{K} on $|f^{(4)}|$, then we know that
$|I - S_4| \leq \frac{K (b-a)^5}{180\cdot 4^4}$.

First we find an upper bound on $f^{(4)}$.

\begin{align*}
f'(x) &= -x^{-2} \\
f''(x) &= 2x^{-3} \\
f^{(3)} &= -6x^{-4} \\
f^{(4)} &= 24x^{-5} 
\end{align*}

On our interval of integration, \emph{{[}1,2{]}},
$|f^{(4)}(x)| \leq \frac{24}{1^5} = 24$. So our upper bound on
$|f^{(4)}|$ is \emph{K = 24}.

Now we simply plug this into the error formula given above to get:

$|I - S_4| \leq \frac{24 (2-1)^5}{180\cdot 4^4} = \frac{24}{180\cdot 4^4} = \frac1{1920}$.
sols_raw:
We will use the hint in the statement of the problem: if we can find an upper bound ''K'' on <math>|f^{(4)}|</math>, then we know that <math>|I - S_4| \leq \frac{K (b-a)^5}{180\cdot 4^4}</math>.  

First we find an upper bound on <math>f^{(4)}</math>.  

<math> \begin{align}
f'(x) &= -x^{-2} \\
f''(x) &= 2x^{-3} \\
f^{(3)} &= -6x^{-4} \\
f^{(4)} &= 24x^{-5} \\
\end{align}
</math>

On our interval of integration, ''[1,2]'', <math> |f^{(4)}(x)| \leq \frac{24}{1^5} = 24</math>.  So our upper bound on <math>|f^{(4)}|</math> is ''K = 24''.  

Now we simply plug this into the error formula given above to get: 

<math>|I - S_4| \leq \frac{24 (2-1)^5}{180\cdot 4^4} = \frac{24}{180\cdot 4^4} = \frac1{1920}</math>.
statement_html: Let \(I = \int_{1}^{2} (1/x)\, dx\). Without computing I, find an upper bound for \(|I - S_{4}|\). You may use the fact that if \(|f^{(4)}(x)|\leq K\) on the interval \([a,b]\), then the error in using Sn to approximate \(\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx\) has absolute value less than or equal to \(K(b-a)^{5}/180n^{4}\).
statement_latex:
Let $I = \int_{1}^{2} (1/x)\, dx$. Without computing \emph{I}, find an
upper bound for $|I - S_{4}|$. You may use the fact that if
$|f^{(4)}(x)|\leq K$ on the interval $[a,b]$, then the error in using
\emph{S}\textsubscript{\emph{n}} to approximate $\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx$
has absolute value less than or equal to $K(b-a)^{5}/180n^{4}$.
statement_raw: Let <math> I = \int_{1}^{2} (1/x)\, dx </math>. Without computing ''I'', find an upper bound for <math> |I - S_{4}|</math>. You may use the fact that if <math>|f^{(4)}(x)|\leq K</math> on the interval <math> [a,b]</math>, then the error in using ''S''<sub>''n''</sub> to approximate <math>\int_{a}^{b}f(x)\,dx</math> has absolute value less than or equal to <math>K(b-a)^{5}/180n^{4}</math>.
